body: Hello! I will try to fix it but could you give me some example codes to reproduce the bug?

I find that the problem is with the parser. For an input like <div ="">, the parser does not treat this as an attribute with no key and no value. Instead, it treats " ="" "as a whole as the key of attribute.

![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71445886/115107272-64d00100-9f9c-11eb-83cd-6ee893184035.png)

XML automatically adds " ="" "  for attributes that do not have val, while HTML does not.

For example, if we input

```
<div a>
```

output of xml

```
<div a="">
```

output of html

```
<div a>
```

We can simply remove the XML auto-add ="" feature to make the results look correct. 

Or we need to rewrite parse so that it can parse attributes with no key and no val. But I think this will result in incorrect output like "< div >", because the program will not print an attribute with no key and no val, so we also need to make the program able to distinguish between "< div >" and "< div ="" >", which may be a big task.

Hello,I found that when parsing the parser treats ="" as attribute name. So while building the xml DOM tree it completes the value to a null string ```
``` In my opinion, since the value of attribute name is empty, does this result of parsing seem more reasonable? ```
```

issue.title: Empty attribute name produces invalid XML output with using xmlParser

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
Fix issue #1474 In my opinion, since the value of attribute name is empty, this result of parsing seem more reasonable ```
``` Added two new variables hasIllegalAttributeName and illegalPendingAttributeName used to record the current key values are reasonable and while building the XML dom tree the illegal key value will change to empty

body:
Had another look and confirmed that the current jsoup parsing of this is correct per the spec, and aligns with chromium. That's odd, but better to stick to the spec here and clean up the XML serializer I think.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/76934/132332109-594c2da1-886d-4e05-813c-f84aa13ac5c7.png)

Particularly, that's an attribute with the key `=""` and no value.

So the fix should be particularly to update just the XML serializer and test for attribute XML validity, similarly (or ideally sharing code with) the W3CDom util class.

OK, attribute names are now normalized & validated correctly for the specific output syntax (HTML or XML). Previously, syntactically invalid attribute names could be output by the html() methods. Such attributes are still  available in the DOM, and will be normalized if possible on output.

issue.title: Change how empty attribute names are handled

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
When parsing <div ="">, the parser no longer treats " ="" " whole as the key of the attribute, but "","" as the key and val.
" ="" " will be retained if we use HTML, but not if we use XML

issue.title: An attribute with a " in its name will be serialized without it

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
We are facing the issue in parsing HTML with attr values that look JSON format with Jsoup1.14.3.jar . But it's parsing fine with jsoup1.13.1.jar Jsoup version: 1.14.3 ## source.html file ``` Try jsoup
``` ## Parsed output from jsoup1.13.1 ``` Try jsoup
``` ## Parsed output from jsoup1.14.3 ``` Try jsoup
``` ## Difference found Jsoup 1.13.1 :cards="[{" brandedcontent":null,"mediainfo":null,"id":4409516,"title":"seguir jugant amb els jocs"}]" Jsoup 1.14.3 :cards="[{" brandedcontent:null,mediainfo:null,id:4409516,title:seguir jugant amb els jocs}] ## Issue @jhy In above ``` brandedcontent:null,mediainfo:null,id:4409516,title:seguir jugant amb els jocs}]``` treating as attr_name and truncating at certain length.
